As the debate about the nation's economy continues in Congress, many Americans are trying to resolve their own individual financial troubles, especially as unemployment numbers continue to grow.

Chicago Public Radio's Adriene Hill reports on one sector of the population facing a particularly tough employment transition.
Jason Jarmoe(ph) served in the U.S.
Army for seven years.
He's a handsome, clean-cut, 33-year-old drinking a cup of coffee at a cafe in Chicago.
He's been out of the military since October of 2003, and has clear memories of his transition from military life to the civilian working world.
Well, it's a totally different mentality.
I mean, you're like, you're talking about two different responsibility levels.
I mean, we're talking about you being solely in charge of a 15 or even $20 million helicopter and then, eventually, maybe even 10 of them.

Jarmoe was able to make the transition, and had some good jobs before the economy tanked.
